1969 Jaguar E-Type Series II 2+2 4.2 Litre 6-Cylinder.  Owned by a discerning collector, this E Type is a show quality car. Having just over 60,000 miles traveled since new, a car of this originality is rare today in the E-Type market.  This is a car that is ready to show or use for road touring. It is a fantastic car both in driveablilty and looks.

The car is finished in the original color combination of Carmen Red with Black Connolly Leather.  The interior is original with the exception of the two front seats. They have been rebuilt with fresh foams and hides from the UK. The smell of the Connolly Hides is still present. The car has just received a Concours quality bare metal respray by one of the leading auto restoration firms in South Florida. From the factory this E Type car is equipped with the options of Air Conditioning and the 3-Speed Automatic Transmission.

While in the current ownership of the last several years, the Jaguar has undergone a full and comprehensive servicing with a British Car Specialist. The services having been preformed include replacing all fluids and filters. The braking system was thoroughly gone through, replacing all four calipers, as well as the rotors and pads. A new pair of auxiliary radiator fans along with a fresh water pump have been fitted. All of the body and window seal rubber were replaced, as the original had begun to deteriorate from age. Also, a new correct OEM, not an aftermarket, windscreen glass was sourced and installed with the fresh seal, due to the original beginning to delaminate. A complete, manifold back Bell Exhaust Stainless Steel system was also sourced and fitted to the car. The exhaust note is fantastic. There has been a new correct steering wheel fitted, but the original will be supplied with the car.

The drivability and handling of the car was improved with a fresh set of Vredestein tires with new inner tubes. The trailing arm bushings have be replaced, along with stub axle seals and the wheel seals. The overall drive quality of the car is tight and responsive, with no play or wandering.

The body is straight and shows no previous evidence of bodywork from corrosion or accident damage. The undercarriage is clean, as is the engine compartment. The chrome trim is bright and free of any major flaws. The rear cargo area and spare tire well are like new. The spare wire wheel spare, the factory jack, lead wheel hammer, and center knock off tool, as well as the original owner's manual are with the car.

Offered here is a professionally restored, low-mileage 1969 Jaguar E-Type Series II Roadster. This is one of the cleanest Jaguar examples we've had the privilege of bringing to market. Enzo Ferrari himself was quoted saying the Jaguar E-Type is ''the most beautiful car ever made,'' and we happen to agree with him. The car was professionally cosmetically and mechanically rebuilt at 22,000 miles. Today, it shows less than 24,000 original miles.

RM Restorations of Chatham, Ontario, notorious Jaguar experts, performed the restoration work, including a new leather interior and new carpeting. Mechanically, the braking system was rebuilt, all new suspension components installed, and a complete tune-up and rebuilt carbs on the original 4.2L/246hp Inline 6-Cylinder engine by a Jaguar specialist. The car is finished in eye-catching red paint over a tan leather interior. It is rust-free and flawless on every surface (see photos).

According the E-Type registry, this car, no. 1R8385, is one of 7,852 left-hand drive open two seaters ever built. The car fires on command and is a great running/driving example. It sounds great and is a blast to drive. With just three-owners, and fresh restoration, and less than 24,000 original miles, this is a great investment opportunity. Concours examples are valued at over $150k, making this car an awesome value at the price offered here. Call or e-mail if interested or to make a reasonable offer. Thank you for looking.

1969 Jaguar XKE CoupeIt has been said many times before but it is always worth repeating, Enzo Ferrari when he saw the first Jaguar XKE was quote in all the newspapers and magazines as saying, "THE MOST BEAUTIFUL CAR EVER MADE".One of our favorite configurations for an XKE in terms of aesthetics is the XKE coupe, the sloping roof line just adds that little bit of extra to the total design of the XKE to truly make it one of the most beautiful sports car designs ever executed.  The second thought in reference to the car in this ad is that color is always very important and XKE's in cream just have a certain amount of extra "POP"!   As you can see from the photos of this 1969 Jaguar XKE coupe that is listed it is strikingly beautiful. It is interesting to note that a previous owner who appears to have had much experience with the early XKE's with their 3.8 engines, decided that while he loved the lines of his 1969 Jaguar coupe, he much preferred the early 3.8 engines to the six cylinder engines that were factory installed in the 1969 Jaguars.  With that in mind he proceeded to replace the 4.2 engine with a 3.8 engine.  The current owner has had the engine super detailed.  It is our understanding from the private seller that the 3.8 engine has under 500 miles since 1988.  Actual mileage unknown.The current owner has driven this car on trips up to about 50 miles and has indicated that it drives just as it should. The manual transmission operates as it should.The cream paint is complimented by the red leather interior. The current owner would like to make note that the radio is currently not working and he believes that it is not the original radio. The 1969 Jaguar XKE coupe in this listing has been fully detailed with all engine and body parts cleaned.  Take a look at the photos to see how exceptionally well that the car does show. The current owner describes the appearance of this car as a beautiful driver but certainly not a trailer queen. Considering how the XKE's have been escalating in price, the reserve is very conservative and you can certainly feel free to bid to win and be happy that you did.

title: 1969 Jaguar E-Type Series II 4.2L Fixed Head Coupé

description: 1969 Jaguar Series II 4.2L Fixed Head Coupé, Blue-plate California car, Jaguar Heritage certificate

. Current owner is a lifelong Jag enthusiast and member of the Jaguar Owner's Club of Los Angeles (affiliated with Jaguar Club of North America). This is a restored So Cal "barn find" that was previously garaged, unregistered and undriven from about 1988 until 2016. Previous registered owner (whom I am informed was just the second registered owner) died in 1987 shortly after paying off the loan on the car. His widow was not able to care for the car, and when it failed a California emissions inspection in or around 1990, it was mothballed and passed from one family member to the next. Last owner's widow gave it to the owner's sister, who gave it to her son, who attempted to restore it for about 12 years before his wife ordered it out of her garage, when the current owner acquired it.
Mechanicals

. Thousands invested in mechanicals to bring this beauty back to life and now she runs like a champ. New wiring harnesses for main engine compartment and alternator completed in March 2018, with extensive other electrical work performed (condensers, relays, fuses, starter rebuilt) in 2016. All new OEM belts and hoses, new aluminum radiator by Cool Cats of NJ, new power brake servo, new master/slave clutch cylinders, entirely new exhaust system including shiny new black manifolds and stainless Bell exhaust pipes and mufflers which sound beautiful and gurgle with joy on the downshift. Mechanical speedometer and dash clock were rebuilt by a recognized expert in Smiths gauges; the clock now works beautifully with a quartz movement for improved accuracy and reliability. Original 4-speed manual gearbox (Gearbox No. 1KE1979) paired with the original 4.2L inline six-cylinder engine. Original Engine No. of 7R4828-9, but this engine is unstamped, possibly indicating that the original engine was swapped out by a dealership under warranty early in its life and the original engine number was not re-stamped onto the new engine block. No air conditioning for the perfect analog driving experience free of complications. Upgraded RetroSound stereo head unit with full Bluetooth connectivity and new speakers for period-correct appearance but modern soundtrack for your weekend canyon drives.  Original copper radiator and Sanyo stereo cassette head unit (non-operating) have been retained in case the new owner wishes to restore them. All records for the last two-year restoration have been maintained and go with the car to the lucky new owner.
Aesthetics
. Dark blue leather interior is like a time warp, having been covered
and

garaged in drought-ridden Southern California for 30+ years.  Silver paint appears to have received a respray sometime in the 1980s prior to being garaged. Paint has a few superficial nicks and scratches. Typical parking lot door dings on the passenger side. One hard-to-discern concave dent on the nose near the grill opening (likely where a small can of paint or a like heavy/blunt object fell on it while in storage), and less than a foot north of that, one convex dent where a mechanic may have closed the bonnet on his tools, leaving a mark in the steel. There appears to be no rust on the car except possibly some superficial surface rust in some crevices.  New Hankook whitewall tires on original chrome wire wheels show their age but are still usable and could benefit from re-chroming at some point. Original spare tire (appears to be unused, with chalk still on the tire) in the boot with tool roll (no jack or knock-off tools, sorry).  Bumpers show well, with some superficial pitting visible upon close inspection. Boot hatch window has received new rubber and chrome trim and is solid and leak-free. Driver's door window received new rubber as well.  Remaining rubber along windows and bumpers is intact but aging.

In short, this is a period sports car with appropriate patina and targeted upgrades that runs like a champ. This car gets more attention wherever it goes than any car I've previously owned. It is a wonderful work of art. If you love Jags and want a "Mad Men"-style time machine, meet your new ride!
